title: Canelo Alvarez says Gennady Golovkin trilogy is 'no challenge'
text:
Canelo Alvarez has downplayed talk of a trilogy fight with Gennady Golovkin and claimed the feared Kazakh looked slow and vulnerable in winning the IBF and IBO middleweight titles last week.

Golovkin looked far less menacing than he did when he knocked out Steve Rolls in June during a laboured points victory over Ukrainian Serhiy Derevianchenko, who many pundits suggested should have won their unification bout at Madison Square Garden.

The heavy puncher's 40th career win has left fight fans hoping he will seal a third contest against Canelo, who handed Golovkin the only defeat of his career during a points win in Nevada in September 2018 following a draw between the pair a year earlier.

Alvarez took a contentious win over Golovkin in 2018 but says a trilogy 'presents no challenge'

Alvarez won the second fight 115–113 on two scorecards, while the third judge declared a draw

Both fighters said they were open to a trilogy in the aftermath of their closely-contested scrap

'That fight presents no challenge to me right now,' Canelo told The Independent, calling Derevyanchenko the winner of Golovkin's unconvincing fight on October 5.

'We fought two times, 24 rounds. I beat him, so he represents no challenge. I said it before the fight and I'm going to repeat it.'

The manner of Canelo's victory over Golovkin, which split the judges after eight rounds and was considered the wrong decision by many critics, means talk of a third fight has rarely quelled.

Mexican superstar Alvarez saw off Daniel Jacobs in their middleweight unification bout in May

Golovkin outlanded Canelo in their original draw, retaining the WBA (Super), WBC, IBF and IBO middleweight titles on a split decision before losing them a year later.

Pound-for-pound number one Canelo derided his main rival's display against Derevianchenko, claiming it had shown that shots to the body were the 'pathway' to hurting Golovkin.

The hugely popular Mexican, whose £278m deal with broadcasters DAZN is the most lucrative in sports history, strongly hinted that he could be swayed by the kind of figures that gave the original fight the third-highest proceeds ever recorded in boxing.

'What he does represent is some good business,' conceded Canelo, who helped to generate revenue of more than £93m in the second fight.

'So if they offer me something really good, maybe the third fight can happen.'

Canelo will fight Sergey Kovalev for the WBO light heavyweight title at the MGM Grand Garden Arena on November 2, making his first appearance since earning a unanimous points decision over Daniel Jacobs on May 4.
